org.jooby

Class Route.Definition

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.jooby.Route.Definition
  • Enclosing interface:
    Route

    public static class Route.Definition
extends Object
    DSL for customize routes.

    Defining a new route

    It's pretty straight forward: 

       public class MyApp extends Jooby {
     {
        get("/", (req, rsp)  -> rsp.send("GET"));

        post("/", (req, rsp)  -> rsp.send("POST"));

        put("/", (req, rsp)  -> rsp.send("PUT"));

        delete("/", (req, rsp)  -> rsp.status(Response.Status.NO_CONTENT));
     }
   }

    Setting what a route can consumes

       public class MyApp extends Jooby {
     {
        post("/", (req, resp)  -> resp.send("POST"))
          .consumes(MediaType.json);
     }
   }

    Setting what a route can produces

       public class MyApp extends Jooby {
     {
        post("/", (req, resp)  -> resp.send("POST"))
          .produces(MediaType.json);
     }
   }

    Adding a name

       public class MyApp extends Jooby {
     {
        post("/", (req, resp)  -> resp.send("POST"))
          .name("My Root");
     }
   }
    Since:
    0.1.0
    Author:
    edgar

    • Method Detail

      • pattern

        @Nonnull
public String pattern()

        Path Patterns

        Jooby supports Ant-style path patterns:

        Some examples:

        • com/t?st.html - matches com/test.html but also com/tast.jsp or com/txst.html
        • com/*.html - matches all .html files in the com directory
        • com/**/test.html - matches all test.html files underneath the com path
        • **/* - matches any path at any level.
        • * - matches any path at any level, shorthand for **/*.

        Variables

        Jooby supports path parameters too:

        Some examples:

        • /user/{id} - /user/* and give you access to the id var.
        • /user/:id - /user/* and give you access to the id var.
        • /user/{id:\\d+} - /user/[digits] and give you access to the numeric id var.
        Returns:
        A path pattern.
